Pneumonia is the most common severe complication of measles and accounts for most measles-associated deaths [ 39]. It can be caused by measles alone or can be secondary to viral infection with adenovirus or HSV (some children have the clinical pattern of bronchiolitis mediated by viruses), or secondary to a bacterial superinfection [ 39, 40]. Measles is one of the causes of Hechtâ€™s giant cell pneumonia, which usually occurs in immunocompromised people but can also occur in otherwise normal adults and children. About 30% of pneumonia cases are caused by bacteria, with the most often isolated pathogens being S. pneumoniae, S. aureus, and H. influenzae. Neisseria meningitidis has also been identified in some cases [ 41, 42]. Rarely, severe pneumomediastinum and mediastinal emphysema may develop [ 43].
